message:
Question about Vagrant:
I understand how it can be easy and helpful to set up Linux VMs using Vagrant (the bash shell will take care of installing/configuring everything).
What about Windows VMs?
Let me walk you through the scenario:
I have a support/test environment where we need to have multiple combinations of versions ready for testing. I have Windows XP/Vista/7/2008/2012 matrixed with versions 9.3/10/10.1/10.2 of the software we're using.
Let's say we have a library of these machines.
Then, for every new case/test we need a separate instance that builds on one of these machines.
How do I do that (using Vagrant or anything else)?
(please let me know if my description is not clear enough)

data.message: I think Virtualbox has something equivalent to Vagrant https://www.virtualbox.org/manual/ch11.html

My understanding so far is that Vagrant sits on top of VirtualBox (that was the first VM engine, then came others like VMware), and does this stuff using simple commands. But that's all I understand so far :)

There is a plugin for Vagrant to run windows VM's 
I haven't tried it myself though
https://github.com/WinRb/vagrant-windows
i don't think that shell can take care of configuration of windows guest systems. try chef
